resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: Sound modifier: a computer running several synthesizers on software.
resource.chars: Sound modifier: a computer running several synthesizers on software.

item.value: <svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><path xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" d="M259.38336,390.74488l166.98499,1068.70396l601.14598,477.57708l1152.19645,-480.91678l-644.56207,-257.15689l-76.8131,-754.77217l-1202.29195,-60.1146v0z" data-paper-data="{"strokeWidth":3,"annotation":null,"editable":true,"deleteIcon":null}" id="rough_path_79531eaa-2cbe-4468-8ea7-d7e452814bf9" fill-opacity="0.00001" fill="#00bfff" fill-rule="nonzero" stroke="#880188" stroke-width="25.83641" stroke-linecap="butt" stroke-linejoin="miter" stroke-miterlimit="10" stroke-dasharray="" stroke-dashoffset="0" font-family="none" font-weight="none" font-size="none" text-anchor="none" style="mix-blend-mode: normal"/></svg>

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
Reappropriating consumer electronics: here, a "wiimote" (a gamepad) is turned into a hybrid instrument. Its motion-sensor emits a signal that is passed on to a midi controller (a piece of hardware which allows the interface between instruments and software). The signal is then sent to a computer. There, the electronic signal of the wiimote is run through several digital synthesizers (seen on screen). This repurposing of an everyday object (a gamepad) is a technologically advanced example of a central practice in noise instrumentation. Everyday objects are repurposed, often in a DIY manner. Children's toys are often <a href="circuit" target="_blank" rel="noopener">circuit bended or short-circuited in order to sound noisier or to create unexpected sounds.
This setup is used by french musician and artist Joachim Montessuis.
resource.chars:
Reappropriating consumer electronics: here, a "wiimote" (a gamepad) is turned into a hybrid instrument. Its motion-sensor emits a signal that is passed on to a midi controller (a piece of hardware which allows the interface between instruments and software). The signal is then sent to a computer. There, the electronic signal of the wiimote is run through several digital synthesizers (seen on screen). This repurposing of an everyday object (a gamepad) is a technologically advanced example of a central practice in noise instrumentation. Everyday objects are repurposed, often in a DIY manner. Children's toys are often circuit bended or short-circuited in order to sound noisier or to create unexpected sounds.

This setup is used by french musician and artist Joachim Montessuis.
